int dfs(int cur, int last3_code, int n, int mod) {

    if (cur == n) return 1;

    if (memo[cur][last3_code] != -1) return memo[cur][last3_code];

    int total = 0;

    for (int c = 0; c <4; c++) { // A, C, G, T (0-3)

        // get the previous three characters from last3_code

        int c0 = (last3_code >>4) &3;

        int c1 = (last3_code >>2) &3;

        int c2 = last3_code &3;

        // form the last4 string

        char last4[4] = { char_for(c0), char_for(c1), char_for(c2), char_for(c) };

        if (ok(last4)) {

            // compute new_last3_code

            int new_last3_code = ( (c1 <<4) | (c2 <<2) | c );

            int res = dfs(cur+1, new_last3_code, n, mod);

            total = (total + res) % mod;

        }

    }

    memo[cur][last3_code] = total;

    return total;

}

The C code structure:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>

#define MOD 1000000007
#define MAX_N 80 // assuming n is up to 80

int memo[MAX_N+1][64]; // memo[cur][code]

// helper functions

char char_for(int code) {
    switch(code) {
        case 0: return 'A';
        case 1: return 'C';
        case 2: return 'G';
        case 3: return 'T';
        default: return '?';
    }
}

int ok(char *last4) {
    for (int i=0; i<4; i++) {
        char temp[4];
        memcpy(temp, last4, 4);
        if (i >=1) {
            char t = temp[i-1];
            temp[i-1] = temp[i];
            temp[i] = t;
        }
        // check for "AGC" in positions 0-2 or 1-3
        if ( (temp[0] == 'A' && temp[1] == 'G' && temp[2] == 'C') ||
             (temp[1] == 'A' && temp[2] == 'G' && temp[3] == 'C') ) {
            return 0;
        }
    }
    return 1;
}

int dfs(int cur, int last3_code, int n, int mod) {
    if (cur == n) return 1;
    if (memo[cur][last3_code] != -1) return memo[cur][last3_code];
    int total = 0;
    for (int c=0; c<4; c++) { // A, C, G, T (0-3)
        int c0 = (last3_code >>4) &3;
        int c1 = (last3_code >>2) &3;
        int c2 = last3_code &3;
        char last4[4] = { char_for(c0), char_for(c1), char_for(c2), char_for(c) };
        if (ok(last4)) {
            int new_last3_code = ( (c1 <<4) | (c2 <<2) | c );
            int res = dfs(cur+1, new_last3_code, n, mod);
            total = (total + res) % mod;
        }
    }
    memo[cur][last3_code] = total;
    return total;
}

int main() {
    int n;
    scanf("%d", &n);
    // Initialize memo to -1
    for (int i=0; i<=MAX_N; i++) {
        for (int j=0; j<64; j++) {
            memo[i][j] = -1;
        }
    }
    // Compute first part's result
    int first_result = dfs(0, 63, n, MOD); // 'TTT' is code 63
    // Second part: 1 if first_result is 0 else 0
    int second_result = (first_result ==0) ? 1 :0;
    // Third part: process second_result (0 or 1)
    // Since it's a single digit, output is same as second_result
    printf("%d\n", second_result);
    return 0;
}

Wait, but in the code above, the initial last3_code is 63 (for 'TTT'), which is correct.

But what about the mod? The first_result is computed modulo MOD (1e9+7). So if the first_result is zero, then second_result is 1, else 0.
